script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, what most people miss when they start reading Moses 1 is this shocking contrast: God appears and declares to Moses, 'thou art my son' in verse 4 and again in verse 6. But moments later, Satan shows up and sneers, 'Moses, son of man' in verse 12. Why that exact phrase, and why right after such a divine vision?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's the mystery that pulls you in, Sarah. It's not just an attack—it's a deliberate counterfeit aimed straight at Moses's identity. Notice how God affirms his divine sonship, while Satan tries to reduce him to something merely mortal. This sets up everything about who we really are.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, a counterfeit of identity? That's fascinating. How does Moses even respond to that?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses clings to what God told him. In verses 13 to 15, he commands Satan, 'Depart hence, Satan,' reminding himself and Satan of God's words: 'I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.' It's powerful—he rejects the fake by holding to the truth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that. So from Moses's view, this is personal temptation right after glory. But what about from God's perspective in this vision?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, multi-perspective shifts everything. From God's view in Moses 1:31-39, after the vision of creations, He explains His work: 'to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Moses is part of that divine work, not just a victim of Satan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Hold on—that ties right into Abraham 3, doesn't it? Because Abraham sees our premortal existence.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Spot on. Here's the pattern emerging: In Abraham 3:22-23, Abraham learns of 'intelligences that were organized before the world was' and 'one among the spirits... more intelligent than the others,' that's Christ. We were there as noble spirits, chosen for this earth to prove ourselves.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So the pattern of divine identity traces from Moses hearing 'thou art my son,' to Abraham seeing spirits before the world was, proving our worth here. That's across dispensations!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and notice this hidden connection most miss: In Abraham 3:25, God says, 'We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' It's the same test Moses faced with Satan—will you claim your divine sonship or settle for 'son of man'?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's remarkable. I never connected those proving grounds directly like that. But what's the historical context here—why does this matter for ancient Israel or us?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. Think about ancient views: The Genesis account starts 'in the beginning,' but the Joseph Smith Translation in Moses gives context before that beginning. Culturally, ancients pondered creation, but these revelations clarify we preexisted as God's children, not just created from nothing.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So it makes the Creation feel immediate, like we're part of the story from before. Here's where it gets powerful for me—how does Satan still use this counterfeit today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Satan tempts with counterfeits, like in Moses 1:13-18, offering fake power or pleasure. What most people don't know is President Russell M. Nelson taught, 'If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity.' Satan confuses that to affect every decision.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly like Moses 1:4,6 versus 12. From Christ's view as the intelligent One in Abraham 3:22, He helps us overcome, bringing immortality and eternal life as in Moses 1:39.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. Jesus bridges premortal nobility to our proving here. Notice the echo: Abraham 3:24-26 shows Christ chosen to make an earth and redeem us, mirroring God's work declared to Moses.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This changes how I read the whole plan of salvation. That opening mystery resolves: Satan attacked Moses's identity to derail God's work, but Moses resisted by remembering who he was.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And we can too. President Nelson said, 'The way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make.' Make your identity as a child of God your most important identifier.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So for modern application, when temptation hits like it did Moses, we say back, 'I am a child of God,' and list choices that honor that.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and look at Abraham 3:22-28 truths: We lived as spirits, Christ was chosen, we're here to prove faithful. That propels us forward in covenants today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I need to understand this more—maybe draw from Abraham 3 like the manual suggests, listing truths about myself and Christ.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Perfect invitation. As families, compare God's message in Moses 1:4 with Satan's in verse 12, and affirm to each other, 'You are a child of God.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's actionable and profound. David, this pattern from Moses to Abraham reveals our divine destiny so clearly.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It does. Ponder these visions this week—your premortal choices echo in today's decisions, all toward God's glory in Moses 1:39.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Listeners, dive into Moses 1 and Abraham 3 with fresh eyes on your identity. Thanks, David—what a journey!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. Keep seeking those truths.
